data.title: Comma numbers
data.statement:
You are given a string [[n]] which represents a number that may or may not contain commas. Your task is to make it a valid comma separated number by adding or removing one comma.

The number must be separated in groups of thousands, so for each 3 digits a comma is added.

When [[n]] is already a valid number, you just output {{0}}.

If [[n]] is not a valid number, you may fix the number to become a valid number by doing only one move, which is either removing or adding one comma at a specific index (The string is 0-indexed):
• In case of removing a comma, you have to output the index of the removed comma as a negative number. When two commas are adjacent, you must remove the last one. e.g., for "1,,000" you remove the one at index 2 instead of index 1.
• In case of adding a comma, you do the same but as a positive number.

In case it is impossible to fix the number in only one move, you have to output {{impossible}}.

The fixed number must be a comma separated number, so for example: {{1000,}} would be impossible. Because you would remove the last comma and add a comma at index 1. That's 2 moves.

<<Examples:>>
• An output of {{-2}} means the comma at index {{2}} should be removed.
• An output of {{2}} means a comma should be added before the character at index {{2}}.
data.inputDescription: <<Line 1:>> A string [[n]] representing a number, it may or may not contain commas
data.outputDescription: The index of the added/removed comma, {{0}} if [[n]] is valid, or {{impossible}} otherwise.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are given a string n which represents a number that may or may not contain commas. Your task is to make it a valid comma separated number by adding or removing one comma.

The number must be separated in groups of thousands, so for each 3 digits a comma is added.

When n is already a valid number, you just output 0.

If n is not a valid number, you may fix the number to become a valid number by doing only one move, which is either removing or adding one comma at a specific index (The string is 0-indexed):
• In case of removing a comma, you have to output the index of the removed comma as a negative number. When two commas are adjacent, you must remove the last one. e.g., for "1,,000" you remove the one at index 2 instead of index 1.
• In case of adding a comma, you do the same but as a positive number.

In case it is impossible to fix the number in only one move, you have to output impossible.

The fixed number must be a comma separated number, so for example: 1000, would be impossible. Because you would remove the last comma and add a comma at index 1. That's 2 moves.

Examples:
• An output of -2 means the comma at index 2 should be removed.
• An output of 2 means a comma should be added before the character at index 2.
Input
Line 1: A string n representing a number, it may or may not contain commas
Output
The index of the added/removed comma, 0 if n is valid, or impossible otherwise.
Constraints
Example
Input
1,000
Output
0
